data.title: Restart doesn't save files.
data.body:
_From @Spown on May 17, 2017 23:59_

- VS Code Version: 1.12.2

Only saves files on debug session start. Not on Restart.

The same is true for Breakpoints. If I remove a breakpoint in runtime and then restrat - the "new" session will break on the nonexistent point. if I save the file manually before restarting - it would work as expected

_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-chrome-debug#432_

data.title: Add feature from #22769
data.body: - `Ctrl+A` now selects all files when focused on the scm viewlet

data.title: Running the contributed command:'npm-script.run' failed.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:16:25.899Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-49-generic
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.0.2|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.4|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.1.9|
|vscode-npm|fknop|3.3.0|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.0|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.9.0|;


---
Cannot run npm package manager on Visual Studio. Gives a error message at top with:

`Running the contributed command:'npm-script.run' failed
`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install or update VS Code.
2. Install npm
3. Run npm by Ctrl+R > Shift+R (or by Ctrl+P and then ">npm").

Fails even with all extensions disabled. Initially failed on Windows 10, now switched to Ubuntu partition (same machine) and still reports the same error. There appears to be no issues here and on **vscode-npm-scripts** (npm's VS Code repository) either.

Console reports by toggling Developer Tools give generic errors:

`Running the contributed command:'npm-script.run' failed.
e.onUnexpectedError @ shell.ts:474 }}(anonymous) @ shell.ts:434
e.onUnexpectedError @ errors.ts:68
o @ errors.ts:88
(anonymous) @ winjs.base.js:43
(anonymous) @ winjs.base.js:38
`

And...

`Object {exception: null, error: "Running the contributed command:'npm-script.run' failed.", promise: n.C…s.d…e._oncancel, handler: undefined, id: 84…}`

data.title: Hard crash (of everything) when terminating running task
data.body:
vscode: April 2017 (version 1.12)
osx: 10.12.4 (16E195)

Similar problem to this #18758

I've setup a task to compile my code:

```json
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "tsc",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["-w", "-p", "."],
    "showOutput": "silent",
    "isBackground": true,
    "problemMatcher": "$tsc"
}
```

If I hit command+shift+b to and run the task, compile works fine. 

If I terminate the task, sometime vscode dies - sometimes everything running in OSX is killed (i.e. everything dies)

----
On a side note - -Yesterday I was investigating why vscode can't debug my mocha tests again, and I found ~15 copies of pgrep running (used killall to kill them)

---- more info from other bug (unfortunately pgrep -V seems broken on osx):

chadbr$ more /Applications/Visual\ Studio\ Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/ms-vscode.node-debug/out/node/terminateProcess.sh 
#!/bin/bash

terminateTree() {
        for cpid in $(/usr/bin/pgrep -P $1); do
                terminateTree $cpid
        done
        kill -9 $1 > /dev/null 2>&1
}

for pid in $*; do
        terminateTree $pid
done
chadbr$ which pgrep
/usr/local/bin/pgrep

chadbr$ /usr/bin/pgrep -V
/usr/bin/pgrep: illegal option -- V
usage: pgrep [-Lfilnoqvx] [-d delim] [-F pidfile] [-G gid]
             [-P ppid] [-U uid] [-g pgrp]
             [-t tty] [-u euid] pattern ...


Thanks -- Chad

data.title: Allow to change Visual Studio Code icon
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4 (16E195)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Change the Visual Studio Code icon to this (rather spiffy) [icon](https://dribbble.com/shots/2436746-Visual-Studio-Code-replacement-icon)
2. Install a VScode update
3. Restart VScode
4. It will complain the install is corrupted
5. Restart VScode again
6. The icon will have changed back to the default one
7. Install is no longer considered corrupted


Other apps like Sublime don't have this problem and work perfectly fine with a different app icon.

I want to (be able to) change the icon because the default one uses some weird faux depth that flies in the face of the flat/2D style almost every other app icon on macOS uses. The alternate one makes it look much more coherent with the rest of my dock :)

data.title: find next/previous re-opens find dialog
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.12.2
- OS Version:Win 10

summary: don't open the "find dialog" when repeating a find.  It doesn't add any value and clutters the screen

I frequently use find next/previous to quickly navigate thru my file when I need to review and/or edit portions of the code.  The find dialog box obscures a portion of my code effectively causing me to have to close it after each ```find```.  I'm unclear on the value of opening the dialog on a find next - if I wanted to start a new search, I would.

data.title: Feature Request: Reload when extensions update finishes

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
While extensions are installed / updated, the Extension icon changes to have a small clock.
When done it swaps to original icon.

Please add a new icon with a similar color exclamation mark or checkmark to denote that ALL updates/installs have finished, and add an event that clicking it will cause a reload message and reload upon accepting it. Instead of me having to scroll again in the extension list and find the first updated extension i can and click its own green "reload" button.

I could trace that to the  ExtensionEditor.css file, adding a new style like:
extension-editor > .body > .content.loading.done  or .content.loading.complete (what ever the right way to name it) and adding a new file loadingdone.svg as its background url.
I just have no idea how to create an actionable event that pressing that button will be the equivalent to reloading VS.

Wish i had more time to make a PR, so instead i just created this issue hoping someone can continue this :)

Alternatively or complimentary, having an option to set in the configuration that it will auto reload upon completing all updates.

data.title: regression: parameterized snippets no longer work
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.13.0-insider (1.13.0-insider, 2fbc979be2bd0fec6dc2af713367b2930f818121, 2017-05-17T08:07:22.195Z)
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have an extension with parameterized snippets (see the [Java extension](marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=redhat.java))
```
"Class Definition": {
    "prefix": "class",
    "body": [
      "/**",
      " * ${name}",
      " */",
      "public class ${name} {",
      "",
      "\tpublic ${name} (${parameters}) {",
      "\t\t$0",
      "\t}",
      "}"
    ],
    "description": "Class Definition"
  },
```
2. when selecting that template during completion, all parameters are gone. This works with the same java extension in Code 1.12.2 (and before)

data.title: VSCode upgrade now causes warnings for plugins on every single tab
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.12.2 (1.12.2)
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install `ruby-rubocop` plugin (or any plugin that generates warnings with an incorrect config)
2. Open multiple tab with ruby files and switch between them
3. On every single tab open:

`execute path is empty! please check ruby.rubocop.executePath config`
![screen shot 2017-05-17 at 11 07 03 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/79215/26169001/050e3d18-3af1-11e7-8d9f-de628c9ac25b.png)

This behavior did not appear until the latest VSCode update restart.

Also, I'm not sure if this makes any sense, because this is correct configuration for this plugin:

https://github.com/misogi/vscode-ruby-rubocop

```
{
  // If not specified searches for 'rubocop' executable available on PATH (default and recommended)
  "ruby.rubocop.executePath": "",
```

data.title: CSS Rename Symbol action on class leaves superfluous dot character
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:20:36.315Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create CSS file.
2. Write `.foo`.
3. Invoke "Rename Symbol" (By default bound to `F2`, or use the Command Palette).
4. Type `.bar`.
5. Press Enter.

Expected outcome
Selector (and its instances) changed to **`.bar`**.

Actual outcome
Selector (and its instances) changed to **`..bar`**.

![vscode-css class-rename-symbol-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1761395/26167443/10adb93c-3b37-11e7-9d75-0344c7052cd7.gif)

data.title: VS Code should disable/deactivate extensions before uninstalling them to prevent uninstall from failing

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2 (I think all)
- OS Version: Windows (I think all)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install the C++/cpptools extension or any other extension that runs a binary from the extension folder.
2. Make sure the Microsoft.VSCode.CPP.Extension process is running (i.e. open a C++ file).
3. Uninstall the extension.

Bug: No "Reload/Install" button appears, because the VS Code uninstaller tries to delete the running extension process while it's still running (so the process never gets removed until VS Code is restarted). The process continues to run because our extension gets no deactivate message. Doing a Reload Window causes the extension to appear uninstalled in the Extensions window, but when you click the Install button it gives the error "Please restart Code before reinstalling C/C++".

Workaround: Doing a Disable/Reload before the Uninstall prevents the error. It would be great if VS Code would do this automatically.

data.title: Feature Request: Add commands to "list" for focusing the first and last child of the current tree
data.body:
Posting this request here per the request of @bpasero. See here for initial thoughts. https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11517#issuecomment-301913181

The gist of this request is that I'd like to be able to somewhat mirror the functionality of vim NERDTree when the explorer is focused by adding keybindings to `shift+j` and `shift+k` to jump to the first and last child of the current list.

Currently, we're only able to jump to the parent of the current list, the first child of root, and the last child of the root with `list.collapse`, `list.focusFirst`, and `list.focusLast`, respectively.

data.title: WorkbenchKeybindingService._cachedResolver stale after ElectronWindow.setup
data.body:
The resolver is discarded and recreated later when extensions are loaded, until then it is stale. It looks like ElectronWindow.setup registering actions deviates from the practice of registering these when a module is loaded.

Maybe ElectronWindow.setup should discard the cache (WorkbenchKeybindingResolver.updateResolver) or the registration should also be done when the module loads?

(Not sure how big a problem this is, I will in my case just register a onDidUpdateKeybindings listener.)

data.title: Do not keep saved what I researched in the search bar.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0 - insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

Steps to Reproduce:

First Situation:

1. Use the search in Active Bar (Ctrl + Shift + F)
2. Go back to the Explorer (or not).
3. Close VSCode or use Reload a Window
4. Open again (ignore if you use Reload a Window)
5. Open the search in Active Bar (Ctrl + Shift + F)
6. See that the item searched for is still there.

Second Situation

1. Use the search in Active Bar (Ctrl + Shift + F)
2. Clear the search.
3. Go back to the Explorer (or not).
4. Close the VSCode or use Reload a Window
5. Open again (ignore if you use Reload a Window)
6. Open the search in Active Bar (Ctrl + Shift + F)
7. See that the item searched is still there.


Note: If I had not used 'Clear Search' and had used 'Reload Window' I could agree to keep. But from the moment I closed the VSCode, I do not agree to keep what I researched ..


Any way to avoid this? This is very boring.

data.title: VS Crashes On Windows Running As Elevated
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enteprise

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Right-click on Code.exe
2. Click  "Run Elevated"

At this point VS will run display the following dialog:

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/28678734/26157556/835c2de2-3ae7-11e7-822c-24c38bf65ff7.PNG)

I can close it and reopen it many times and I get the same error every time I run as elevated. However, the issue does not occur when ran without privileges (by just double-clicking Code.exe or clicking on the VS shortcuts)

And I NEED to run VS code as elevated as it is the only way for me to update it on my machine as I don't have admin rights.

data.title: Geometry support

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I often need to record screencasts with VS Code, and need it in a specific position and size on screen. 

Most X11 based application allow for a `-geometry` switch.

I realize VS Code is Electron-based, and not X11. However, is it possible to support this switch?

Perhaps as follows:

`code --geometry 1280x720-37+50`

where the value is `[{WIDTH}][x{HEIGHT}][{+-}{XOFF}[{+-}{YOFF}]]`
